pn-01.prompt: What is the primary difference between a 'Local Notification' and a 'Remote Push Notification'?
pn-01.explanation: Local notifications (like an alarm or a timer) stay on the device. Remote notifications are triggered by an external server to re-engage the user.
pn-01.interviewTip: For your JS Mock Interview app, a 'Local' notification would be perfect for a reminder to practice tomorrow.

pn-02.prompt: Which service does React Native use to deliver notifications to iOS devices, even when using Firebase?
pn-02.explanation: Even if you use Firebase, Google eventually has to hand the message over to Apple's APNs to reach an iPhone.
pn-02.interviewTip: This is why you still need an Apple Developer Account and .p8 certificates even when using Firebase.

pn-03.explanation: Your server sends messages to this token. If the user uninstalls and reinstalls the app, the token usually changes.
pn-03.interviewTip: Always send the token to your backend database during the app launch or login.

pn-04.prompt: How do you handle a notification click when the app is completely closed (Quit state)?
pn-04.explanation: getInitialNotification is a 'one-time' check that returns the notification data if the app was launched by tapping that notification.
pn-04.interviewTip: This is the most common place where 'Deep Linking' logic starts after a user taps a push.

pn-05.prompt: What is the purpose of 'Notification Channels' on Android?
pn-05.explanation: Android 8.0+ requires channels. Without a valid channel ID, notifications will not show up on modern Android devices.
pn-05.interviewTip: On iOS, this concept doesn't exist; users can only toggle notifications on or off for the whole app.

pn-06.prompt: What happens when a 'Silent' (Data-only) notification is received?
pn-06.explanation: Silent notifications carry a data payload without a 'title' or 'body'. They are used to wake up the app to download new content quietly.
pn-06.interviewTip: Be careful: iOS and Android both limit how many silent pushes you can send to prevent battery drain.

pn-07.prompt: Which of these are required to enable Push Notifications on iOS?
pn-07.explanation: iOS is very strict. You need all these settings and a real device to test the full flow from server to handset.
pn-07.interviewTip: Newer Xcode versions/Simulators have added limited support, but a physical device is still the industry standard for testing.

pn-08.prompt: What is the role of the 'setBackgroundMessageHandler' in React Native Firebase?
pn-08.explanation: This handler runs in its own specialized task outside of your main React component tree.
pn-08.interviewTip: Keep this function 'pure' and avoid using hooks or complex UI logic inside it.

pn-09.explanation: This is a UX term. High-frequency, irrelevant notifications are the #1 reason for app churn.
pn-09.interviewTip: Mention 'Notification Personalization' and 'Frequency Capping' as solutions to this problem.

pn-10.prompt: How do you request notification permissions from the user in React Native?
pn-10.explanation: requestPermission() returns the authorization status (authorized, denied, provisional). On iOS, this triggers the system permission dialog.
pn-10.interviewTip: Always check the current permission status before requesting to avoid annoying users with repeated prompts. On Android 13+, you also need to request the POST_NOTIFICATIONS runtime permission.
